author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello - Given the potential for multiple clots to develop rather rapidly, a single  325 mg. aspirin is not excessive at all. Hopefully the vitamin therapy can help set the other components back into a better alignment, but meanwhile the aspirin is an excellent anticoagulant that is a lot less of a nuisance than, say, coumadin, and quite possibly just as effective.   To emphasize the answer to your last question, yes, your are at risk of developing one (or more) clots. You've had one,  and  that one was not that  remarkable in  itself, but now that you are known to be MTHR C677T positive, there is no ignoring the potential for additional clots. One  325 mg aspirin seems   like a pretty easy regimen. Just be sure to take it!  Best of luck to you.

title: 21 yr old daughter with recurring blood clots in legs
content: My daughter was diagnosed in February with a blood clot in her right leg. It was determined to be in a superficial vein. The treatment prescribed was 2400 mg of ibuprofen per day, heat compresses and support socks.  Two months later, she now has three additional clots, one more in her right leg and two new ones in her left. Doctors have done ulstrasounds (several) and a lot of blood work. They haven't figured out what is causing the clots. Her only risk factor is birth control pills, which they took her off when she got the first clot in February. The doctor wants to do a CT scan of her torso, which we are in the process of attempting to schedule but our insurance is making things difficult.  In the meantime, I am concerned about her continuing to get clots and am wondering why she has not been given blood thinners? Is it because the clots are in superficial veins? Also, any theories as to what would cause blood clots in a young woman?  Thanks from a worried mom!
posted_time: Post  by Pepperspray » Tue May 01, 2007 11:37 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: I would agree that she should have a work up for clotting illnesses such as factor V leiden (roman numeral V), and prothrombin 20210.  These types of diseases make clotting much more likely.  You are correct that the superficial veins to not pose as much threat as a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) so this may be the reason that her doctor has not recommended blood thinners (which carry their own set of risks).  You may want to have her discuss the idea of taking a baby aspirin daily with her doctor.  This can help prevent clot formation and is relatively safe (but again does have a few noteworthy side effects that should be discussed).   Clot formation is multifactorial.  In women, estrogen is a big risk factor.  This is the reason that oral contraceptives are generally recommended against with blood clots.  Best wishes.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Argylebairn, Generally speaking, signs and symptoms of a DVT (Deep vein thrombosis) when it occurs in the lower leg are: swelling, bluish discoloration or redness and warmth, tenderness in the calf especially when the foot is pulled upward, pain when walking (typically in the calf). Treatment typically consists of hospitalization for administration and monitoring of blood thinning medications, bedrest, to prevent a Pulmonary Embolism  where the clot breaks loose and travels to the lungs, and of course providing pain relief. DVT's do not subside without treatment. There are many risk factors one of which being inactive or sedentary for a long period of time such as during travel. Superficial thrombophlebitis is a clot in one of the superficial veins instead of the deep veins. The thrombus in this case usually adheres (or sticks) firmly to the vein wall and does not typically dislodge as sometimes happens with a DVT. In this condition, the area becomes red, warm and tender and typically feels like a piece of cord under the skin. Treatment for this condition does not generally require hospitalization. Pain is decreased by the use of NSAID's (Ibuprofen etc.) Symptoms usually subside over a few days time.  Untreated DVT's may develop into a life threatening emergency situations and if there is any question regarding symptoms, persisting or worsening etc. an evaluation is certainly warranted. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Stroller  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Apr 23, 2007 11:10 am
title: I have had 3 confirmed DVT's
content: Hello there. I am a realatively speaking healthy for the most part 43 yr old male. I am not a doctor but dealing with the onset of blod clots is something I am extremely familiar with. If a clot is setting in in one of your legs you can easily associate the feeling with that of either a major muscle strain or cramp that just does not allow you to get comfortable. If you attempt to walk the pressure alone feels like you leg is being clamped off from the pressure.         The skin temputer will elevate localized and may radiate to the upper quarants of the limb then return to a colder feeling. There will not be a body increase in overall temp. Swelling will begin and will subside after resting the limb, such as in the morning after sleeping, if you can at this point. When speaking of blood clots for the most doctors do not worry too much about superficial ones or if they appear below the knee. When speaking of DVT the pain will begin to become unbearable to attempt to support full body weight.          To check for swelling apply light indented pressure from one finger, then remove quickly to check for rebound or indent remaining. When a clot has developed in the deep vascular area applying and releasing pressure will not show a color change. When the condition of DVT is establishing the pain will spread from the ankle region up above and into the thigh area. At this point mobility will become tasking at the least. The flesh coloring may become that of appearing as a sunburn in lower area and this is because of the lack of circulation.         Treatment consists of hospitalization of up to 5 days to modify clotting factors to proper level via a heprin IV and oral anti coags of Cumadin of varying mgs. The docs know this all too well. I have DVT in both legs and again in my right thigh that migrated into a puliminary embolism. When that happend it felt similiar to having a busted rib pressing into a lung while trying to cough up blood. Sitting with the feet elevated above the heart for periods of 1/2 to one hour during the day is more likely than not. Protime levels need checked regularly and more than likely a supply of either Warfrin or Cumadin will be required. Common swelling of the feet, ankles and calves will occur. The chances of leg ulcers and brutal edema are associated side affects.                  In short if you develop a clot it will start off feeling like a bad cramp that will not stop.

author: heavenlyangel  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Apr 04, 2007 3:32 pm
title: Blood clot again?
content: I am now 20 (21 in May) but when I was 17 (almost 18) I was about 5 months pregant when I was put into the hospital with 2 blood clots, one superficial and one DVT. They put me on Lovenox thoughout the rest of the pregnacy and after I gave birth they put me on Coumadin. After being on that for a few months and going to a specialist they did some blood tests and told me everything looked fine and I could stop taking the meds. That it must have just been from the pregnancy that I got the clots since there was really no history of it. They said I would only have to worry about going back on them if I got pregnant again.  Now I have been noticing ( and I don't know if I am just paraniod of it happening again or what) but my left leg (the one that had the clots) always seems to be more swelled up than the right. (not near as bad or big as it was with the clots though) But it is a significant difference between the sizes. Also every once in a while that leg will just get a pain in it and I get really scared and wont let any one touch it,( my fiance will want to massage it to make it feel better) but incase it is a clot, I am afraid of it breaking loose so I wont let him touch it.  And for the past couple of weeks every once in a while I get these warm sensations that go runnig down my leg. (the best way to describe it is that it feels like I am peeing down my leg, but on the inside) I have just been blowing them off, not thinking much of it. But then my fiance said something like 'well what if your blood is having small blockages and thats when you feel that warmth is when the blockage breaks free. And it could be related to the clots.'  So it got me thinking again and also a little worried.  So I have a couple questions. Is it normal for my leg to still swell up even though the clot is suposed to be gone? And do the warm sensations have anything to do with possible clotting?  Do you think I may be getting another clot or is it just still after effects? (or am I just paranoid?)  Thank you in advance!!!
posted_time: Post  by heavenlyangel » Wed Apr 04, 2007 3:56 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Blood clot again?
content: Dear Heavenlyangel,  One of the complications of having a deep venous thrombus in the leg is destruction of the valves of the veins where the clot was. The function of such valves is to make blood go in a forward direction and prevent it from going in a backward direction. If this happens, the blood in the veins usually stagnates and this leads to a condition known as post-phlebitic limb where there is pain and edema in the affected leg in addition to some skin changes as well.  i think you should be evaluated by your doctor to tell you how to deal with such comolication if this is the case.  i can not tell you without examining you and getting an ultrasound of the legs whether or not you have a new blood clot.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

posted_time: Post  by Apreal » Sat Mar 24, 2007 4:34 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello Apreal - Your bruising could be a cause for concern or it could be something as simple as bumping into something in the middle of the night. Tell me, are these bruises just on your legs or are they in other places as well? Do they appear in a random pattern or do they appear symetrically on both sides of your body? (as in the same place on both legs, etc.).   If this is due to a vitamin definciency it would most likely be Vitamin K, which helps make our clotting factor. Failure to include adequate green leafy vegetables in one's diet could lead to a Vit. K deficiency.   It's possible also that the anti-depressant you're taking might  have an obscure side effect that could affect clotting, or if you've been taking frequent, higher doses of NSAIDS (such as ibuprofin as found in Advil).   Some basic blood work might be in order to rule out a vitamin deficiency, blood disorder or some form of anemia.   Good luck to you and if you can add any information it might help clarify the picture somewhat.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear LaDonna, I appreciate your efforts to describe the exact location of the problem in your leg, and the obvious careful thinking you have put into deciding what is wrong.  Without being able to see you directly, and assess your leg first hand, it is difficult to come up with a definitive diagnosis. There are so many things that can cause or contribute to lumps and bumps, and it really needs to be addressed with diagnostic equipment and tests that can better pinpoint the problem and the underlying cause. It seems somewhat unlikely that an incident that occurred 8 months ago would all of a sudden now cause an acute problem such as you have described.  At the same time, it is possible that an unresolved cut may have not healed properly, and contributed to a slowly developing problem that has now gotten bad enough to warrant your concern. In either event, I would strongly suggest that you see your primary physician, and if you do not have one to go to one of the walk in clinics, or urgent care facilities for a medical professional to evaluate. From what you are describing, this may not resolve on its own unattended, and may signal a problem that may quickly become of urgent concern (if it is not so already!)

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear LaDonna, I appreciate the clarification.  One of the things I teach is that Pain is not your enemy - it is a sentinel - it tells you when something is wrong.  It is always wise to identify the etiology of a pain.  Sometimes pain and soreness and even hardened areas on our extremeties are merely the result of a localized trauma such as banging your leg on a table or other hard object.  Sometimes it can be more serious - such as a hematoma (oversize blood clot - if you will) under the surface of the skin.  This latter one deserves further inspection because the source of the bleed should be identified. My concern for you is that you are obviously concerned.  Our bodies "talk" to us, and when we listen well we eat well, live well, and treat our bodies well.  If yours is telling you something is wrong, and you are not able to easily identify just exactly what is wrong, then a specialist in bodies - called an MD - might be needed to help you do so.  I still suggest you have your concerns evaluated at your primary care physician's office, or at a walk-in clinic.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Blood clot formation is a little bit variable.  Clots can form rapidly (minutes) or grow more slowly.  If there is concern for DVT's the most appropriate test is a doppler ultrasound to look at the blood vessels and assess for clots.  Your symptoms have many possible causes.  Embolising clots may cause your symptoms.  Other possible causes may include panic attacks, vasculitis, and other nerve problems.  I would strongly recommend that you see your doctor for an examination.  DVT's can potentially be serious and should be evaluated for if there is a possibility they exist.  Best wishes.

author: Marceline F, RN  Nurse Posts: 229 Joined: Wed Feb 28, 2007 1:54 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear Sandscollins, According to your post, you had a blood test (probably a D-Dimer) that came back positive, and caused your MD to order a CT of the chest to rule out/rule in a Pulmonary embolus.  I understand that this test came back with a result of "low probablilty for a PE", which typically would clear you for any clots in the lungs. However, the fact that you are experiencing calf pain is cause for alarm - because a DVT (deep vein thrombosis) which is frequently situated in the lower extremeties, would also cause a D-Dimer to read high.   I strongly encourage you to go immediately to the nearest Emergency room and tell the ERMD of your current concerns. They will probably order an ultra sound of your leg (s) to determine if there is a clot there.  A clot anywhere in the body is cause for significant concern, as it can break off and travel through the blood stream and lodge in the brain, heart, lungs, kidneys, etc.  The treatment for this generally includes some form of anticoagulation therapy - the choice being predicated upon the nature of the clot and the location. There are other treatments included as well, involving in most cases complete bed rest for a period of time to be determined by the MD.  Please address this urgently.
posted_time: Post  by Marceline F, RN » Sat Mar 10, 2007 8:55 pm

author: AlamoCity  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Mar 07, 2007 6:50 pm Location: San Antonio
title: Question about valves in blood vessels being destroyed
content: Can untreated superficial thrombophlebitis destroy the valves in blood vessels, or is that something that can only be done by DVT's?   Also, do the blood vessels in thighs have valves in them?  Thanks in advance
posted_time: Post  by AlamoCity » Wed Mar 07, 2007 7:26 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Question about valves in blood vessels being destroyed
content: Dear Guest,   There are 2 types of blood vessels, veins and arteries.  Superficial thrombophlebitis is a condition that affects superficial system of veins.  Veins contain valves that make the flow of blood towards the heart and prevent its "backward" movement away from the heart.  If the superifical vein is affected by inflammation or thrombus formation (two different disease processes), and if inflammation or thrombus formation happens to involve the area where a valve is present, most probably this valve will be affected and will be destroyed leading to regurgitation of blood and its stagnation in the veins, leading to dilatation of the veins, a condition known as varicose veins.  Yes, the veins in the thigh contain valves.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and I hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Thu Mar 08, 2007 8:21 am

author: dinobub  Guest Posts: 9 Joined: Tue Aug 10, 2004 10:56 am Location: US
title: plavix vs aggrenox
content: Dear Doctor  -- I am a 66yo male ischemic stroke victim, which happened in Nov. 05. I have since been treated with Plavix once a day, and I have, on my own, also added aspirin, 325 mg once a day, which may be a bit risky.   I have since been told by 2 other neurologists that they would have started me on Aggrenox instead of Plavix.  The best I can find out by internet research is that Plavix acts by coating platelets with a smooth surface so they won’t stick together, and the active ingredient in Aggrenox, ER-DP, acts as a vasodilator. Is there any information  or study addressing the theory that a combination of these would add symbiotically ?
posted_time: Post  by dinobub » Fri Jan 26, 2007 2:59 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Hello dynodub - I apologize for being so late in replying to your question but it somehow got by me. Oh, by the way, I'm not an MD, but an allied health professional. Still, I think I can answer your question. Here goes:  Aggrenox is, as you accurately point, out a vasodilator, or at least contains something (dipyridamole) which has that property. It also, however, contains aspirin. While on paper Plavix and Aggrenox should provide increased protection, and Aggrenox has become very much favored by doctors for its protective capabilities regarding strokes, adding aspirin to a Plavix regimen increases one's bleeding potential to an undesireable (because potentially dangerous) degree. While aspirin has anti-coagulant properties, Plavix reduces the viscosity of blood. The combination could, in a worst-case scenario, lead to a very dangerous and difficult to stop bleed.   If you feel you might be better served by Aggrenox than Plavix (a controversial issue) I would strongly suggest you contact your doctor, asking if he would be willing to prescribe a trial of Aggrenox. If he doesn't feel it's appropriate he probaby has his reasons and since I don't have access to your chart  (nor the authority of an MD), I wouldn't second-guess such a decision on the part of any MD.   In any event I would discontinue the aspirin unless specifically recommended by your doctor, for the reasons stated above. You've already noted that your self-medication with the aspirin might be risky, and you are correct. Since Plavix does not cause blood vessel dilation, any signifcant increase in blood pressure could result in a bleed on the brain that would be far more serious than an ischemic stroke.  Hope this helps answer your question.
posted_time: Post  by John Kenyon, CNA » Thu Feb 15, 2007 10:47 am

author: sarta  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Dec 10, 2006 2:49 pm Location: new york city
title: My left hand is turning blue
content: I am 23, female.  No real history of anything except slightly high blood pressure.  I am taking inderal.    My left hand has been bluish for the last two days. Not strikingly so, but it is definitely blue compared with my right hand. It's not cold, and it doesn't hurt, but it feels a bit like I've been lying on it or something. What should I do? What makes this happen? Thanks :)
posted_time: Post  by sarta » Tue Jan 09, 2007 5:29 pm

author: John Kenyon, CNA  Nurse Assistant Posts: 2846 Joined: Wed Dec 20, 2006 1:05 pm Gender: Male Location: Laurel, MD
title: [no title]
content: Dear sarta - Given your description of the hand as being somewhat bluish as compared with the other one, and given that there is some sensory distortion or loss in it, there are two possibilities that come to mind right away, probably working in tandem to cause this: first, one would expect this sort of presentation possibly in someone who suffers from Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS), a condition in which the structures of the scalene triangle (composed of the collar bone and first rib, an area where the ulnar nerve and blood vessels feeding the arm and hand pass between) become a little too close together, putting pressure on the nerves and blood vessels serving the arm and hand. This is a common, if controversial finding, and can cause pain, numbness, tingling in the hand on the affected side, as well as chest pain, shoulder discomfort, poor venous return, etc. Not serious but often annoying and sometimes causing limiitation of movement or difficulty doing repetitive tasks, it can be the result of an anatomical abnormality, poor body mechanics or an injury such as whiplash.   The other possible cause, and one which might show up this way because of a mild underlying TOS that hadn't caused problems previously, would be the use of Inderal, which can, in many patients, cause coldness and even some discoloration in the hands and feet due to constriction of capilaries as one of its side effects. If this is of new onset, it may be because you started the Inderal and perhaps have a mild TOS problem on the affected side.   Your doctor could do a simple screening test that involves taking your pulse at the wrist on the affected side while elevating and manipulating the arm. This isn't the gold standard but can be a useful tool for determining if TOS may be present. Often there is nothing much worth doing about it. If it causes considerable pain and limitation of motion, TOS can sometimes be surgically corrected, but usually it is managed with some simple exercises, posture awareness and practicing good body mechanics. It's not serious in any event, but you might want to have your doctor take a look at this to be certain there isn't some other, really obscure and unusual cause for the symptoms. It seems pretty likelly it is a combination of TOS and Inderal use, but of course only your doctor can say for certain.   Good luck to you with this, and please keep us updated as to any changes or anything new you may find out about it.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   The chest contains many organs, like the heart, lungs with its pleural covering, esophagus, muscles, ribs, tendons, and nerves. They all can be the source of the pain felt in the chest.   - It sounds like muscle spasm is the cause of your symptoms.   Muscle spasm alone can cause this pain which can be an unidentified cause but in many cases is the result of inappropriate posture for long time like traveling, driving, carrying heavy objects, and certain types of work.   Muscle spasm can also occur due their inflammation (viral infection) or overexertion of the chest wall muscles following heavy long attack of coughing. Tenderness over the affected areas is usually present.   - Pleurisy is an inflammation of the pleura, which is a double-layered membrane covers the lungs separating it from the rib cage. Viral infections like flu, are the most common cause of Pleurisy. The pain is felt as sharp pain which get worse by Coughing, sneezing, moving and deep breathing.  Auscultation of the chest shows a characteristic sound known as pleural rub.  Other causes (less likely): -Pain due to rib or chest wall bone disease (costochondritis of viral origin) is also another cause of chest pain.   In all of these conditions the chest pain is usually aggravated by taking deep breath and cough.   Cardiac causes should be excluded in any case of Chest pain although your symptoms are not typical.   Direct clinical examination is essential.  I advise you to follow up with your doctor.  Keep us updated.  Best regards.

author: joepeh  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Dec 01, 2006 10:20 am
title: INR test protocol
content: I am a 70 yr. old male with a cardiac pacemaler implanted. I have been monitored for warfarin use by family doctor since implantation almost 3 years ago.  Minor adjustments to warfarin level have been made during this period.   I recently moved to a new city and have a new physician.  His technician used the same machine my previous doctor's tech did.  I observed several differences in protocol which were disturbing: 1) She inserted a test strip into the machine, then stuck my finger applying the blood drop directly to the test strip, not via pipette as done previously.   2) to get a large enough drop of blood she squeezed or pinched my finger. 3) The first test strip produced an error. She put in a new test strip, and pinched my finger even harder to get more blood from the original stick.  This test failed as well. 4) She put in a third test strip and pinched my finger REALLY hard to get blood from the original stck (now about two minutes has elapsed). 5) This third test yielded a reading of relatively (compared to past) low INR.  I am concerned because I had been led to believe that the blood from a finger stick must be sampled within 15 seconds of the stick.  Was this multiple attempt to get a reading from one stick correct?  Doesn't pinching the finger hard cause other fluid to exit the stick wound?  By the way, this technician did not wear any hand gloves during any part of the procedure.  Thanks for any advice or comments......

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi thenunn, TIA's (Transient ischemic attack) may present with symptoms similar to that of a stroke (CVA) but typically resolves with in a few minutes to with in a 24 hour period. (Unlike a stroke where symptoms are typically  present longer than a 24 hour timeframe). Symptoms may include weakness, numbness of the face, arm, leg, one the same side of the body, dizziness or lack of coordination, slurred speech, dizziness, visual disturbances, etc. Temporaryy interuption of blood flow to the brain is the causative factor. Diagnostics may include, a carotid ultrasound (to identify if there is decreased blood flow in the carotid arteries), arteriogram (to identify if there is blockage in one of the other vessels), etc.  Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

content: Hi nelly145, Your symptoms do not appear to correlate with a pulmonary embolism. A PE would not be resolved by the medication xanax. author: Dr. R. Perala  Medical Doctor Posts: 12 Joined: Tue Aug 09, 2005 6:02 pm Location: Cave Creek, Arizona  Contact:   Contact Dr. R. Perala       Website
title: Syncopal Episode
content: Hi:  I would recommend that your wife have some further testing to confirm the cause of her syncope (the medical term for "fainting").  The most common cause of syncope is what is known as vasovagal syncope...A classic case of vasovagal syncope would be a slightly dehydrated person in a warm room who feels faint and weak, maybe a little nauseated and shaky, sees their vision dim, then passes out for a few seconds.  This is very common and not a serious medical problem.  Anxiety may also cause syncope by hyperventilation.  This is also not a serious medical issue, but would require better treatment of the anxiety or panic attacks to prevent recurrence. There are however other more serious causes of syncope.  It is possible for a young woman to have a heart arrhythmia that would produce a sensation of anxiety, breathlessness, chest pressure and syncope.  Your wife should definitely have an ECG to rule out this possibility.  A 24 hour recording by a Holter monitor would be ideal (this is a little device you wear on your belt for a day, that records your heart rhythm). Many medications can also predispose to syncope, particularly blood pressure medications and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs).  What is the medication that your wife takes for anxiety? Did the doctor do any blood tests (this would be important to rule out low blood sugar or anemia, among other things)?  Does your wife make any movement while she is unconscious?  Does she wake up immediately, or does she seem confused when she wakes up? While most cases of syncope are not due to a serious medical illness, it is very important to have some further testing done to rule out the rare, but potentially serious causes.  Please return to your doctor asap!  - Reid Perala, MD (medical resident)
posted_time: Post  by Dr. R. Perala » Sat Mar 11, 2006 1:06 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi nelly145, Was the DVT treated? DVT's require hospitalization which would include treatment with a blood thinning medications. Untreated DVT's continue to enlarge causing a more extensive occlusion of the vein, interferring with circulation, not to mention if it would become dislodged it may cause a serious life threatening emergency. Most (treated) DVT's disappear without incidence, however, there is of course a risk of recurrence. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi nelly145, Ultrasound is one of the standard diagnostic studies for identifying a DVT. There are usually specific symptoms associated with a DVT. A thrombosis may affect superficial veins. Superficial thrombophlebitis may cause inflammation, pain, tenderness, warmth, and the vein feels much like a cord. This usually lasts a short amount of time, doesn't require hospitalization for treatment and since the vein is not encompassed by contracting muscles as the deep veins are, rarely does this condition cause any sort of life threatening complications.  If however, you are still experiencing symptoms, you may want to have a re-evaluation. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: DoctorJohn  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Tue Feb 14, 2006 5:00 am
title: DVT unlikely
content: Dear Nelly,  The constellation of symptoms you describe is most unlikely to be caused by a DVT.   Moreover, if the underlying problem was due to a DVT then you would expect some swelling (and possibly hardness) in the right calf and this clearly is not the case.  No, your symptoms sound much more likely to be due to a disc lesion in your lumbar spine and I suggest that you have an MRI scan arranged to confirm this.  Best wishes,  DJ

title: D-dimer and pulmonary embolism
content: I recently went to the emergency room with chest pain and feeling like I was not getting enough oxygen.  I was getting 100% oxygen but felt like I couldn't get a deep breath.  My heart rate was normal and blood pressure was normal.  I have been experiencing pain in my right calf muscle for approximately two-three weeks.  It is not constant and occurs at random times.  The doctor was concerned about a pulmonary embolism so ordered a chest X-ray, an EKG, a D-dimer and a CT scan of my chest.  All tests were normal.  I am still having pain in my chest that comes and goes and also the feeling of not being able to get a deep breath.  I am a 26 year old female.  I do take oral contraceptives but I don't smoke and am not overweight.  I have no prior surgeries and no medical problems that I am aware of.  the only medication I am taking are the oral contraceptives and now Nexium.  Should I be concerned about the possibility of a blood clot since I am still having pain in my calf?  Does a negative D-dimer mean I don't have a blood clot?
posted_time: Post  by cqlas » Tue Feb 07, 2006 2:49 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi cqlas, Is your calf or lower leg swollen, red or warm to touch? Does the pain increase when walking or flexing your foot? A D-Dimer is a test typically used to help identify certain conditions including a pulmonary embolism. Elevations, due to the nonspecifity of this test, may be caused but several conditions, for example, recent trauma or surgery in the preceeding three months, fever, infection, blood clots anywhere in the body, and malignancies. Was there any other diagnostics completed, for example, an ultrasound of your leg, or a VQ scan? If not and you are still experiencing symptoms, I would strongly suggest that you inquire with your physician about these diagnostic studies. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: holmes282  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Jan 22, 2006 9:23 pm Location: North Carolina
title: Reoccuring blood clot at 24 years
content: I am a 24 year old female who is at the gym running at least 3 miles and lifting some weights at least 3 times a week  and have recently been diagnosed with a DVT in my right arm.  My dr. hospitalized me for 2 days and put me immediatly on 60mg of Lovenox twice a day and 500mg of coumadin once a day.  After about two weeks my blood thinned to a thickness of 2 and my dr. took me off of the Lovenox and kept me just on the coumadin.  Since then my blood clot has been back twice and I would be put on the same amount of Lovenox (60mg) and my dr. would up my dose of coumadin each time.  Long story short, I am currently off Lovenox and on 750mg of coumadin everyday except Tuesday and Thursday I am on 1000mg of coumadin.  The dr. took blood work and learned that my Protien C levels were 40 (he said that it should be around 75) This past weekend I have been having the same symptoms and am quite sure that the clot is beginning to form again. I have an appointment to see a hemotology specialist at the end of this week.  As I am sure you can imagine, I have been racking my brain and  am really nervous.  My dr. hasn't really given my any best and/or worse case scenarios.  Can this be linked to cancer of any kind?  Do you think that this could be a terminal illness.  Could you give me a possible best and worse case scenario?  Is this a typical thing for a 24 year old female who is phyically active to have?  I appreciate all of the help you can give me. :)

title: Re: Reoccuring blood clot at 24 years
content: holmes282 wrote:I am a 24 year old female who is at the gym running at least 3 miles and lifting some weights at least 3 times a week  and have recently been diagnosed with a DVT in my right arm.  My dr. hospitalized me for 2 days and put me immediatly on 60mg of Lovenox twice a day and 500mg of coumadin once a day.  After about two weeks my blood thinned to a thickness of 2 and my dr. took me off of the Lovenox and kept me just on the coumadin.  Since then my blood clot has been back twice and I would be put on the same amount of Lovenox (60mg) and my dr. would up my dose of coumadin each time.  Long story short, I am currently off Lovenox and on 750mg of coumadin everyday except Tuesday and Thursday I am on 1000mg of coumadin.  The dr. took blood work and learned that my Protien C levels were 40 (he said that it should be around 75) This past weekend I have been having the same symptoms and am quite sure that the clot is beginning to form again. I have an appointment to see a hemotology specialist at the end of this week.  As I am sure you can imagine, I have been racking my brain and  am really nervous.  My dr. hasn't really given my any best and/or worse case scenarios.  Can this be linked to cancer of any kind?  Do you think that this could be a terminal illness.  Could you give me a possible best and worse case scenario?  Is this a typical thing for a 24 year old female who is phyically active to have?  I appreciate all of the help you can give me. :)  Dear Holmes,  As I always do, let me preface this by saying that I am just a medical student and not a full physician yet.  So also as always, none of the information provided is supposed to be substituted for the sound medical advice of your physician.    Now, in regards to your situation, I can definately understand the frusteration you must be going through.  I hope you are coping well while your doctors try to manage your care.      I don't know if your doctor has explained how clotting necesarily works in your body but hopefully this will better help you better understand the pathophysiology behind your condition.  Just like there are factors in your body that help you form clots when there are injured vessels; quite intuitively, there are also factors that help break up these clots.  Most pertinent to your case, a substance called antithrombin III is formed by your body and helps break down clot forming factors to prevent you from over clotting.  Just like antithrombin, another anticoagulant factor naturally produced by your body is called Protein C.  Protein C also aids in breaking down clots.  So as a result, a deficiency in any of these factors may cause you to hypercoagulate and cause a DVT.   So when your doctor put you on enoxaprin (Levanox), this drug was meant to accentuate the features of antithrombin III and enhance the break down of the clot.  The coumadin that you are placed on is a drug that prevents the metabolism of Vitamin K.  Vitamin K is important because it is needed in order to form various clotting factors.  Also important however, is that vitamin k is essential in the formation of Protein C and S.  The same protein C and S that are required to break down clots.  So, by putting you on coumadin, the drug is preventing the metabolism of vitamin k, which is a significant molecule necessary for the formation of Protein C, hence - your lab work shows a decreased protein C level.  So the bottom line is, your Protein C levels are low because you are on coumadin.  They could also be low because you had a genetic deficiency of Protein C but given the current scenario, your coumadin is leading to the low Protein C count.  However, if your physicians take you off coumadin, give you vitamin K, and your protein C levels don't elevate - you might have an inherent protein C deficiency (although this isn't very likely).    I hope this helps and doesn't confuse you.  Just to reassure you again, I would not be worried of any type of serious cancerous condition if I were you.   Sincerely,  Student Doc

title: Residual effects of PE
content: I am a female, 33 years of age, 5'7", 130 lbs.  I had a PE almost two and a half years ago, most likely contributed to the use of birth control.  I  tested positive on the Factor V Leiden test; ALLELE 1, mutation present.  (Whatever that is.)  I understand the interpretation on this report, though.    My blood pressure is normal.  I don't take medications, vitamins other than ibuprofen for occasional pain.  My job is very sedentary, but I swim at least three times a week, 1 h 15 m to 1 h 30 min per workout.  My questions are:  1)  Are there any residual effects from a PE?  My PE was very painful, and I feel the area has healed well.  I will have pain/pressure -- not anything to take medication for -- about an inch to my left of my sternum, even with my nipple, where it feels as if someone is poking with their finger, small area, but internal.  Any thoughts?  2)  On occasion, I will have achiness in my upper thighs, more noticeable around my cycle.  Before I had my PE, my hips hurt where it would be hard to even walk.  It's not the same pain.  I just don't know if I'm having possible circulation problems where I should let my doctor know.    Any information would be appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by Anne-Teeter » Sun Jan 22, 2006 10:19 pm

author: Dr. A. Madia  Medical Doctor Posts: 207 Joined: Fri Jan 06, 2006 6:50 am Gender: Male Location: India
title: [no title]
content: Hi.  The first question: PE blocks one of the pulmonary arterioles and causes infarction of that perticular portion of the lung. Most PE are very minute ones , not causing a large enough infarct to have any lasting symptoms. If you had a large PE your condition at the time would be a serious one and you would be critically ill and you would be on ventilator.   If the PE was small it would heal and in any case it would not throw any symptoms on the chest wall after this much lapse of time. This pain is more in the nature of musculoskeletal one.  The second question: Heaviness and pain in the inner thighs is common around the periods as pevic blood flow increases and there is generalised engorgement in the area.  For your height you maintain a good weight and keep up your exercise schedule. never again take oral contraception.  A. Madia

author: pilotgirl  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Thu Dec 29, 2005 6:12 pm Location: TX
title: Chest pain after ovarian cyst rupture last week
content: I had, as stated in the topic title, an ovarian cyst burst last week and had the extreme pain that went with it (low blood pressure resuled along with tachycardia and syncope) and went to the ER where I underwent CT scans and blood tests.  EKG came back normal.  I developed an infection two dyas later as I was not prescribed an antibiotic at the outset.  I was then put on 400mg avalox and had been on Vicodin and Naprosyn.  I am still on avalox but last night developed pain on the right side of my chest and around to the back side of my right shoulder blade.  I again went to the ER and again experienced syncope and tachycardia.  They did blood tests and chest x-rays to test for a pulmonary embolism but both came back negative, EKG came back normal. (I have since read that you can get false negative reports on the blood tests and that it does not always show up on early chest x-rays).  I was diagnosed with costalchondritis (?) and/or pleurisy.  My questions are 1) can my original ovarian cyst rupture be considered a trauma bad enough to cause a PE and 2) if I am on antibiotics, is it reasonable to believe that I could develop a bacterial infection such as pleurisy?  Sorry to be so long winded but any answers I could recieve would be most helpful.  Thanks for your time.
posted_time: Post  by pilotgirl » Thu Dec 29, 2005 7:22 pm

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Dear Pilotgirl,  I am sorry to hear of your traumatic event, hopefully all is going well for you.  Ovarian cysts are extremely painful but usually do not cause any type of threat for pulmonary emboli (PE).    Pleurisy is the infection of the parietal and visceral pleuras which line the inside of the rib cage. When a breath is taken, they rub together and this causes great pain.You are on an anti-bacterial medication which would probably stop a bacterial infections but pleurisy can also be caused by smoking, bacterial or viral infections or it may have an idiopathic cause. The pain in pleurisy will start suddenly and painfully in a stabbing fashion when you take deep breaths and can be felt in the lower chest area and around to your back.  Pulmonary Embolism (PE) is a blockage in the lungs blood vessels that is usually caused by air, fat, particle, fluid or blood clot traveling from another part of the body. When the ER department did the pulmonary (lung) scan on you they probably looked at the blood flow through your pulmonary vessels to see if there was a blockage of blood flow. If you think you have a high probability of getting a PE have your doctor do a blood test to see if you are susceptible to clots.

author: JohnQPublic  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 02, 2005 11:05 am Location: OH
title: Question About Side Effects of Coumadin
content: Hello, I was diagnosed with 3 blood clots (DVTs) in my calf at the beginning of April. Since then, I have been on coumadin. I see that side effects of coumadin could be dizziness and fatigue, but I am now getting to the point where I can barely function. I am so light-headed and fatigued that it is difficult to perform any regular duties. Additionally, I have no appetite and have lost about 10 pounds in the last 2 weeks. I am a 42 year old male. I also have hemochromatosis and hypothyroidism. My synthroid has been raised after checking my TSH once I begun coumadin therapy. Is it possible these symptoms are from the coumadin? The hematologist I went to said that coumadin would not cause these effects, but these symptoms are getting progressively worse. I have an appointment with my family doctor next week. I am wondering if he would go along with doing another ultra sound of my leg to see the status of my clots and then allow to go off the coumadin a couple months early. Thank you very much for any input. Sean
posted_time: Post  by JohnQPublic » Tue Aug 02, 2005 11:14 am

author: up40  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Wed Aug 03, 2005 12:37 pm Location: Michigan
title: re: side effect of coumadin
content: Hi Sean,  I'm a 40 year old RN &  have an extensive DVT in  my femoral vein and have been on Coumadin since Feb of this year.  I have had the DVT since March of 2004 and do not recommend requesting to go off of your coumadin until your DVT is gone.   My family doctor took me off of my anticoagulant after 4 1/2 months and started me on an aspirin a day and I developed 2 new clots. Back to square one.    My advise to you would be to get an emergency appointment with your doctor or go to a walk in clinic or ER & get checked for a small pulmonary embolism, which may cause you to feel lightheaded and tired. You shouldn't be feeling so exhausted and lightheaded that you can't do your usual daily activities.  Do you have shortness of breath with activity, a cough or chest pain?   I think you should also have your TSH checked again to see how you are responding to your new dosage of Synthroid.   As you probably already know it could be due to the hemochromatosis,  so you'll probably need to get that checked too. I've been having problems with lightheadedness in the last 2 weeks too, but my blood pressure has been on the low side and I get PVC's (preventricular contractions) so I think mine is due to that.  The thought has crossed my mind that I should maybe get checked for a PE too.  In fact that is why I came to this site today.  I'm getting tired of feeling lightheaded and not being sure what is causing it too.  It's not to the point that it's debilitating for me though, it just comes and goes.   I wish you luck Sean !  Let me know how it turns out. My e-mail address is  a_z5590@yahoo.com  It's nice to have support from someone going through similar problems.  They should have an online DVT support group.  Take Care

author: esorami  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Thu Dec 02, 2004 2:10 pm Location: so cal
title: Coumadin
content: My mother's dr keeps increasing her coumadin and she is up to 6mg a day now. what causes her blood to thicken so much and is there some way she can keep her blood thin? she is 83.
posted_time: Post  by esorami » Thu Dec 02, 2004 4:30 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear esorami, Warfarin dose really depends on her INR (International normalized ratio) results and the target INR which her doctor wants to reach. For stroke and infarction that would mostly lie in the range of 2.0-3.0. As for what causes her blood to thicken, well, there are many causes. I would put atherosclerosis in your mother's case at the top of the list. Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Fri Dec 03, 2004 1:06 am

author: R. Zein, Pharm D  Pharmacist Posts: 157 Joined: Tue Jul 12, 2005 9:16 pm Location: USA
title: warfarin
content: The dose of coumadin ( WARFARIN) is usually adjusted based on the INR, in patients with infarctions usually, the goal is to keep the INR: 2-3, for patients with mechanical valve replacements, the goal is to keep it 2.5-3.5. there are many risk factors for causing blood to become thicker, atherosclerosis, atrial fibrilattion, hyperlipidemia (high lipids), diabetes complications, some blood clotting factors deficiencies, and smoking. I do not have information about your mother's medical conditions, however , since she is taking warfarin at home, it is very important, to regularly check her INR, because there seem to be lots of drug-drug interaction, as well as food-warfarin interaction , which may either potentiate the blood thinnig effect of warfarin, or decrease its effectiveness, making it less effective is resolving the blood clots. and for that, i may recommend watching or avoiding vitamin K containing food products as they may reverse the action of warfarin. usually the dark green vegetables contain high contents of letuce. Some drugs when taken together with warfarin, can also affect the latter drug. Check to see with your mother's doctor, whether she is taking some drugs that may affect it, and remember , that warfarin dosing remains to be dosed according to the measured INR. thank you and hope that helped.
posted_time: Post  by R. Zein, Pharm D » Wed Jul 27, 2005 11:48 am

title: Odd-looking bruise
content: Recently I spent a whole day travelling by subway, then train, then bus, then plane and had to lug my luggage (weighing 50 lbs but on wheels) sometimes up steps while also wearing a heavy backpack on my back.  (My other bruises from this trek look like normal bruises...and I don't remember them either.)  I don't remember this injury or blow but on the underside my right forearm near my elbow is a bruise 2 1/2 to 3 inches inches across.  I thought I had a mosquito bite because of the bump in the center of the bruise but there was never any itching.  Now 6 days later the bruise is fading but the bump is still there and remains pale while the purple around it is fading.  The bump is somewhat tender.  What caused this?  Is this a burst blood vessel?  Will the bump go away (dissolve)?  Thank you, in advance, for your time.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ? OLECRANON BURSITIS
content: If the swellng is behind the elbow, it is suggestive of olecranon bursitis.  Olecranon bursitis may follow a traumatic accident, such as a fall  onto the back of the elbow, or a hit on the elbow or it may seemingly pop up out of nowhere in people who rest their elbows on hard surfaces. In your recent travels, any of these  incidents may have happened unnoticed.  Show it to your doctor for confirmation. If the diagnosis is correct, treatment is simple. Come back and tell us if this guess was correct.   Dr Anthony Solomon Consultant Physician, Tropical & Genitourinary Medicine

Looking at a black and white picture in a Gray's Anatomy book...it looks like the nearby muscle might be a Flexor Carpi Ulnaris.  Is that the same place you are talking about in your reply?  (BTW...Thank you for your quick reply!)

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: ?? BACTERIAL CELLULITIS
content: Pictures are not close-up views and are unclear,  but suggestive of bacterial cellulitis, which is a spreading infection of the skin.  The portal of entry of the causative bacteria in cellulitis is a bruise. If it is caused by the Streptococcus bacteria, it is referred to as erysipelas.  The area of skin affected is usually warm, red or purplish, swollen and enlarges daily. Please see the doctor immediately to confirm the diagnosis and initiate treatment. The condition has to be confirmed by your doctor and my apologies if an attempted diagnosis by visual inspection is not  correct.  Dr Anthony Solomon
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Anthony Solomon » Thu Jul 21, 2005 4:47 pm

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: [no title]
content: Another possibility here is ecchymosis, which would produce a bluish-black mark on the skin caused by the release of blood into the skin either through injury or spontaneous leakage of blood from the blood vessels. This however, would not cause the skin to be  warm or swollen, and tenderness would only be present if it was caused by trauma. Let us know what physical examination by the doctor revealed.  I note that you placed  your post in the Clots and Anticoagulants forum.  Are you taking any anticoagulant medication or do you suffer from any conditions that would cause spontaneous bleeding?

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Michaelii, Generally speaking, for a DVT (blood clot) standard therapy for in hospital treatment is IV heparinization. After the problem is resolved, treatment with a medication taken by mouth (warfarin, plavix, etc.) depending on the preference at the treatment facility and physician  is used. Lovenox is a medication generally used for treatment at home, given by  injection and is quite useful and effective for some people but it is also exceptionally expensive. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: [no title]
content: Hi smt1977, Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome is one of the hypercoagulable syndromes. You can easily get clots, strokes, heart attacks, DVTs, pulmonary emboli. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi cinders, Aspirin usage may benefit people with coronary artery disease, people who have had heart attacks, angina, bypass surgery, etc. The usual recommended dosage is 81mg per day (a simple baby aspirin). However also keep in mind that this medication stops the blood from clotting as quickly as usual. It is also effective for pain relief in larger doses (325mg etc.) Do you have risk factors for heart disease? I'm not saying that a small dose of aspirin will cause any problems but they are usually taken by people for pain relief or who have high risk factors for heart disease. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi slam, Cellulitis is inflammation of the skin and may be caused by a bacterial infection. When bacteria enters  the skin by any means, insect, animal bite, injury or trauma, etc. it causes the skin in that area to become inflamed, red, and tender. As the infection spreads so does the inflammation, redness and tenderness. Again I'm not saying that this is your problem but it is something I would consider. In my opinion, I would have an evaluation done.  Sincerely, Rntdj

author: tmill009  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jun 10, 2004 4:58 am Location: Australia
title: Travel after having a DVT (blood clot)
content: Hi Everyone,   Just a quick quesiton regarding DVTs.  My dad is 79 years old and about 18 months he had a DVT in his right leg (after having a knee operation).  I was just wondering whether or not it is safe for him to travel by air since having his DVT???  Would travelling overseas on a plane be dangerous?  Thanks,   Tim.
posted_time: Post  by tmill009 » Thu Jun 10, 2004 5:01 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Although the added risk of developing a DVT caused by travelling appears to be low, it can be reduced even further by exercising the legs at least once every hour during long-distance travel. This means taking regular breaks if driving, or walking up and down the aisle of a coach, train or plane.   The muscles of the lower legs (which act as a pump for the blood in the veins) can be exercised while sitting by pulling the toes towards the knees then relaxing, or by pressing the balls of the feet down while raising the heel.  Other preventive measures:Don't take sleeping pills. These cause immobility, increasing the risk of DVT  Drink adequate fluids  Avoid smoking  Avoid beverages which contain alcohol and/or caffeine both before and during the flight  Avoid crossing legs when seated  Walk around the cabin whenever you can  Stand up in your seat area and stretch your arms and legs  Carry out the foot and leg exercises: as stated earlier. Wear loose fitting comfortable clothes when travellingIf you have any of the additional risk factors listed below, you should seek medical advice before travelling. In particular, you should discuss: The advisability of anti-embolic stockings  The advisability of low dose aspirin before flight  The advisability of anti-coagulant medication or other prophylactic measures before flight Some doctors recommend taking aspirin or their anticoagulant before travelling because of its blood thinning effects. If in doubt, seek advice from a doctor.  People who have one or more of the risk factors mentioned earlier should seek medical advice before travelling.  Anyone who develops swelling or pain in the leg, or breathing problems after travelling should seek medical advice urgently.  Risk factors for DVT: major injuries, or paralysis  surgery, especially if it lasts more than 30 minutes, or involves the leg joints or pelvis  cancer and its treatments, which can cause the blood to clot more easily  pregnancy and childbirth - related to hormone changes that make the blood clot more easily and because the fetus puts added pressure on the veins of the pelvis. There is also risk of injury to veins during delivery or a caesarean. The risk is at its highest just after childbirth  taking a contraceptive pill that contains oestrogen. Most modern pills contain a low dose, which increases the risk by an amount that is acceptable for most women  hormone replacement therapy (HRT). For many women, the benefits outweigh the increase in risk.  other circulation or heart problems

posted_time: Post  by Izzy » Wed Apr 21, 2004 1:36 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Blood Clot (dvt)
content: Dear Lzzy,  Having repeated blood clots in the veins of the legs or anywhere else without provoking factors (such as laying in bed for a long time, having surgery or travelling lets say in a car or plane for prolonged periods of time) can be suggestive of a disorder where the blood has a higher tendency to clotting than the normal.  This could be related to having a congenital disorder, where the naturally occuring anticoagulants in the body are deficient and/or defective.  It could also be related to  - Cancer. Your friend should be checked for cancer. - Heart failure which leads to blood stagnation.  Coumadin is the treatment of choice if your friend has a higher tendency to clotting and if your friend has an underlying precipitating factor (like cancer) till this precipitating factor is gone.  An index of 2.5-3.5 is good. But if the dvt is recurrent eventhough the index is within therapeutic range, i think your friend has to see a specialist in blood diseases so that he checks why she is getting recurrent blood clots and decide whether she needs an even higher doses of coumadin and run an even higher index.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear Joey, Before I start jumping to conclusions I would like to know what your temperature is. Its best take directly as soon as you wake up in the morning. It still looks like Raynaud's phenomenon to me. Did they give you any reason why they have excluded it? Raynaud's is not really a disease of the vessels as it is a faulty reaction by the heat regulating system in the body. The heat regulating system which is controlled by a center in the brain controls the body temperature by either  1. preserving the body temperature at times of cold: It does this by constricting the vessels in the periphery 'e.g. the skin' to shift the warm blood away from the cold environment and to warm the more vital internal organs of the body. In effect this leads to cold extremities and skin.  2. decreasing the body temperature: It does this by the reverse reaction. It dilates (expands) the vessels in the periphery so that the warm blood is closer to the environment and away from the vital internal organs.  In Raynaud's there is excessive constriction of the vessels in response to cold. Another important factor is age. The heat regulating center becomes more lazy and less coordinated. Ativan is a benzodiazepine wich may lead to hypothermia but usually in larger doses than the one you are taking.  Regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear Nancy, Exanta is a very promising new drug. It acts as an anticoagulant but by a different mechanism than that used by coumadin. I have checked the literature for you but unfortunately have not come accross any studies performed on patients similar to you. However, it is assumed that it should replace warfarin for all its indications; however, that remains to be seen. Unfortunately, as of today, the drug hasn't yet been approved by the FDA or in Europe for that matter, as it is still in its early phases of testing. The only way exanta is given to patients is through their enrolement in clinical studies. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hand, There is absolutely nothing to worry about. The superficial veins of the hand run in a layer of skin called the subcutaneous fat. This, as the name says contains fat padding the structures that pass through it. What you have is normal. The tendons beneath the vein are able to move it. There is no danger from excessive friction between the tendon and the vein as they are covered by fat. The fat eliminates any friction between these structures and effectively insulates them from one another.  Regards,

content: Dear Tiffairy,  Thank you very much for using our website.  D-dimers unfortunately are very non-specific. Meaning that they get high in lots of conditions. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: D-dimer and contraceptive pills.
content: Dear Tiffairy,  Thank you very much for using our website.  After looking into the litterature, i found one article that mentionned a study that looked into the relation between contraceptive pills and d-dimer and it was found that d-dimer is increased in females taking contraceptive pills in comparison to their female counterparts who were not using contraceptive pills. So this could be the cause of your elevated d-dimer.  If you stop taking the contraceptive pills, your blood will go back to normal in that it will not be as prone to coagulation. And no it does not mean that if you have a blood clot that it will dislodge from its place and go somewhere else.  Isolated pelvic vein clots are not that common. Pelvic vein clots are commonly formed by extension from clots of the leg veins.   Risk factors for pelvic vein thrombosis include trauma, surgical procedures involving the pelvis and hypercoagulable states (conditions in which the patient is more prone to coagulation than normal due to some diseases). It has also been reported as a complication in the postpartum period. Also, thrombosis of the pelvic veins,  can be seen in women with pelvic inflammatory disease.  The data regarding the clinical significance of pelvic vein thrombosis, however, are limited. This may be partly due to the difficulty in diagnosing this condition.  Diagnosis can be made by direct venography (injecting a dye into the veins and see whether there are clots or not. Other possible way is by doing a magnetic resonance venography of the pelvic veins.  Once more, thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: D-DIMER 1500, WHAT DOES IT MEAN?
content: Thanks so much for your response and your research. Why do pelvic vein clots because of Pelvic Inflammatory disease and is this a common or rare complication? How does one know if they have PID? Thanks

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Tiffairy,   Pelvic vein clots as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease is not a common occurrence.  To know that one has pelvic inflammatory disease, one must have symptoms in the form of fever, lower abdominal pain and tenderness, cervical motion tenderness. Then if the doctor suspects that the patient has pelvic inflammatory disease, tests are done to confirm the diagnosis and these include an endometrial biopsy, transvaginal sonography or other imaging techniques showing thickened fluid-filled tubes and laparoscopy in difficult cases.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Raynauds and 3rd Degree Burns.
content: Good Afternoon,  I have had Raynauds for 9 years.  About 1 year ago I sustained 3rd degree chemical burns to my legs.  Moreover, I have Raynauds to my legs, feet, and hands.  Since the burns I have noticed a dramatic increase in the attacks.  Furthermore, I have had more of a burning, tingling sensation in the area of the scars.  I have researched this topic at the library in Gainesville, Florida, however, I find nothing publised. I would be interested in your thoughts and opinions.  I thank you so much for your time.  Lora Radiches, Jax, Fla
posted_time: Post  by Lora1957 » Thu May 22, 2003 1:46 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Raynaud's disease
content: Dear Lora1957, Sorry to hear about all the hardship you must have gone through. Raynaud's disease is primarily a disease of the vascular system as you well know. The blood vessels do not supply enough blood to the peripheral areas of your body (e.g. toes). A 3rd degree burn is capable of altering the vascular system in that area further. Normally when a part of the body receives little blood there are mechanisms that try to compensate. One of these mechanisms is the creation of collateral blood supply. Now the role of collateral blood supply in a disease like Raynaud's would be questionable but all the same these compensatory mechanisms could be impaired all the same by a 3rd degree burn. This would lead to an increase in your symptoms.  Here is an article which may be useful to you:  http://www.john-libbey-eurotext.fr/arti ... 6/399-404/  Best regards.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Heaviness
content: Dear Ella,  What do you mean by heaviness? Do you mean that you have weakness in your arm and leg or a sensation that occurs to someone when his hand or foot goes to sleep and then start to wake up?  i do not know about your health background.  Weakness could mean that this is a warning symptom for a stroke if in the proper setting.  Heaviness only on the other hand could mean that there is either  1. Nerve problem going on, or 2. Brain problem. This could be an equivalent to a stroke as well.  My advice to you is to visit your physician to be checked either way because this might be a prelude to a stroke. author: twinkptrp  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Jan 22, 2003 9:20 am Location: Philippines
title: Whole body numbness - transient ischemic attack, mild stroke
content: Hello, doctor!  My friend told me that she was awaken last night by this pins-and-needles sensation all over her body (except the head part) and lasted for a couple of minutes. she was claiming that she might have experienced a mild stroke ( transient ischemic attack). but i have thoughts about it, since manifestation of a stroke is almost always hemilateral. could she be right? what other diseases present  this kind of symptom?or is this only brought about by too much stress? I was thinking of a heart/vessel problem. By the way, she's only 31 y/o and has no previous history of any kind of illness. Please enlighten us. Thanks in advance.
posted_time: Post  by twinkptrp » Wed Jan 22, 2003 9:34 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Wole body numbness
content: Dear guest,  Thank you very much for using our website.  Being 31 and a female and having a heart condition is rare although not unheard of especially if the patient has other risk factors like diabetes, family history of heart dieases, high blood pressure, smoking, high cholesterol, lack of exercise.  The symptoms that your friend had are non-specific and can represent symptoms of lots of diseases. Having a heart attack while having this sensation is uncommon but could happen although with your friend age and gender i would suspect very much.  If you or she are still concerned then the best way of action should be to seek medical advice at her doctor's office and have a stress test done.  About a transient ischemic attack, it does not have to be on one side of the body and the symptoms are not typical of a transient ischemic attack as well in this case.  i would worry if this recurrs but if it does not i would not worry about it.  Once more, thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and hope this helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
